item.title: Code
item.description: JavaScript function $initHighlight(block, cls) { try { if (cls.search(/\bno\-highlight\b/) != -1) return process(block, true, 0x0F) + ` class="${cls}"`; } catch (e) { /* handle exception */ } for (var i = 0 / 2; i < classes.length; i++) { if (checkCondition(classes[i]) === undefined) console.log('undefined'); } return ( <div> <web-component>{block}</web-component> </div> ) } export $initHighlight; JSON [ { "title": "apples", "count": [12000, 20000], "description": {"text": "...", "sensitive": false} }, { "title": "oranges", "count": [17500, null], "description": {"text": ".

item.title: Math
item.description: KaTeX is switched off by default. Enable it by setting kaTex = true in the [options] section of ./config/_default/params.toml. Example 1 Excerpt taken from Supernova Neutrinos Markdown The average energy of the neutrinos $\langle E \rangle$ emitted during a supernova explosion is of the order of 10MeV, and the neutrino luminosity at the early epoch of the explosion is approximately $10^{52}\mathrm{ergs\cdot s^{-1}}$. Therefore, the number density of the neutrinos at the radius $R$ is $$ \begin{equation*} n \sim 10^{18} \mathrm{cm^{-3}} \left(\frac{100\mathrm{km}}{R}\right)^2 \left(\frac{10\mathrm{MeV}}{\langle E \rangle}\right).
